column1: The '''Eastfarthing''' was one of the four [[Farthings]] of [[the Shire]]. Its westernmost point was the [[Three-Farthing Stone]], its eastern border was the [[Baranduin
column2: Brandywine]] River, and its southern border was the River [[Shirebourn]]. Within its bounds were the regions of [[Bridgefields]], the [[Marish]], and [[The Yale]].<ref name=map>{{FR

column1: Geographical features were the forest of [[Woody End]], the hills of [[Scary]] and the [[Green Hill Country]] and the rivers [[Stock-brook]], [[Thistle Brook]], and [[The Water]].
Several roads that connected the towns and villages were [[East Road]], [[Causeway]] and [[Northway]]<ref>Causeway and Northway are not named on the map.</ref>

column2: 1630}} many [[Stoors]] from [[Dunland]] entered and settled in the Eastfarthing.<ref>{{App
column3: TA}}</ref> Throughout that Age, whenever [[Bree-hobbits]] visited the Shire, they mostly reached [[Buckland]] or the Eastfarthing, as these were closest to their home, and rarely ventured further west.

column4: Pippin]] travelled from [[Bag End]] to [[Crickhollow]] much of their trek took place in the Eastfarthing, where they first encountered the [[Nazgûl
column5: Black Riders]] and were protected by [[Gildor
column7: I3}}</ref> Continuing eastward, the crossed the fields of the Marish and met [[Farmer Maggot]] before they left the Eastfarthing on the [[Bucklebury Ferry]].<ref name="mushroom"/>

column1: Upon their return from their adventures in the south, Frodo, Sam, Pippin, and [[Meriadoc Brandybuck
column2: Merry]] discovered the evil afoot in the Shire when they entered the Eastfarthing. On the first night they stayed at the uncomfortable guard-house near the [[Brandywine Bridge]]. At Frogmorton the Travellers were “arrested” and the spent the night at the Shirriff-house. The next morning they journeyed westward and left the Eastfarthing.<ref>{{RK

column1: By the time of the [[War of the Ring]] the inhabitants of the Eastfarthing were still mainly Stoors, especially in the Marish, and they were known for many peculiar names and strange words uncommon in the Shire.<ref>{{FR
column2: Hobbits}}</ref> Some months of the [[Shire Calendar]], in the Eastfarthing had different names, the ones used in the [[Bree Calendar]].<ref>{{App

column1: In muddy regions, such as the Marish, Hobbits wore boots and were house-dwellers, like [[Farmer Maggot]].<ref name="mushroom">{{FR
''[[The Golden Perch]]'' inn was said by [[Peregrin Took
column2: Pippin]] to serve the best beer in the Eastfarthing.<ref name="mushroom"/>
